body:
Ok, I think there are two requests in there, and a proposed way of addressing these.

The two requests: residuals and in-sample values.

Regarding residuals, I fully agree that there should be an easy way to return them!
But, I don't think this is a concern of the `BaseForecaster`.

There also already is a way to obtain residuals from a forecaster, it's the `Detrender` - simply detrend with the forecaster you would like to get residuals of - it's a transformer, and the output gives you the residuals.
Perhaps we should say this in the forecasting tutorial, since it's not obvious from the name "detrender"?

Regarding in-sample fitted values: this is definitely a `BaseForecaster` concern in my opinion, but doesn't this already exist? Is this not what you would get when you run `predict` at the values that have already been seen? Simply pass a fixed forecasting horizon with the indices that you've observed.

`forecaster.fit(y).predict(fh=y.index)` or `forecaster.fit(y, fh=y.index).predict()`. Does this work for you?

What I'm wondering, should there perhaps be a `fit_predict(y)`, which, if `fh` is not passed, defaults to in-sample forecasts, i.e., `fh=y.index`? There currently isn't, but it might be the "in-sample" convenience method.

Feedback on whether it is what you need, or whether it's "obvious" would be appreciated.

body:
for forecast combination, you may like to look at the `HedgeExpertEnsemble`, it may do what you want, i.e., re-weight depending on errors or forecast residuals.

Would be nice to hear from you whether you think that's what you need or not, and whether it should be made clearer in the tutorial.

Regarding residuals:
from a [discussion on Slack](https://sktime-group.slack.com/archives/CQVH0NJ1M/p1628935128001400) with @ngupta23 : As some models e.g. from `statsmodels` have residuals internally calculated, the best would be to have a default function `def _get_residuals(self)` or sth in the parent which is called then in `fit()` after` _fit()` was called that calculates residuals based on in-sample predictions. So we could overwrite this function in the child class for some models that provide this internally. So the parent class would get an additional attribute `residuals_`. Not sure if this should be optionally or always calculated. The reason for optionally would be that for large data sets, we maybe dont want to store the residuals in `self`.
What does everybody think?

alternative suggestion: a `ResidualsTrafo` transformer that wrape a forecaster? That way, it can be used as a transformer in pipelines.

We could do both, of course - though let's think carefully before we proliferate base class methods.

I think you can just run:
```python
transformer = Detrender(MyForecaster())
residuals = transformer.fit_transform(y)
```

oh yes, we already have the `ResidualsTrafo` and it's called `Detrender`.

Perhaps we should introduce an alias `Residuals` and/or add a "computing residuals" section to the tutorial?
So just to clarify, `Detrender` will give the true in-sample residuals (in-sample prediction MINUS in-sample actual)?

I see [it now](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/3c54d8d1e66ec7863d12738e64c1f733d0e6a22e/sktime/transformations/series/detrend/_detrend.py#L141). 

> Perhaps we should introduce an alias Residuals and/or add a "computing residuals" section to the tutorial?

Yes, that will be a useful addition (from a clarity perspective) even though it will be an alias.

issue.title: [ENH] Past predictions over train set

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
> **Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I was wondering why can't we get past predictions (by that I mean predictions made by the model on the train set) in sktime, actually one of the most fundamental ways to compare models is to compare their performance on train set relatively to test set performance and see if they're over-fitting: if the model performance on train set is way better than it is one the test/validation set. But in sktime we can only (I guess) see future predictions because of the fh argument that starts at 1 (as the first prediction after train set) which means we can only compare y_pred to y_test.

> **Describe the solution you'd like**

I think this needs a refactoring of how forecasters treat the `ForecastHorizon`. either forecasters should be able to accept negative values in their `fh` argument (kinda off) or maybe (as in statsmodels) the new forecasts should start at `len(y_train)`.

> **Additional context**

This makes a big difference for models that can be overfitted aka models with lots of hyper-parameters such as prophet where adding more and more seasonalities with high order can make your future predictions worse but your past predictions better. Actually all models that allow multiple seasonalities (BATS and TBAT) can over-fit easily but with this you'll be able to see it with your eyes.

body:
> 
> 
> I think you can just run:
> 
> ```python
> transformer = Detrender(MyForecaster())
> residuals = transformer.fit_transform(y)
> ```

Hi @mloning , Would it be possible to store the residual information in the forecaster object when fit is called for it? This would be more efficient since usually, the residuals are called only after fitting the forecaster (for fit assessment). Having to call another fit after that in `transformer.fit_transform` would be doubling the fit effort in terms of time. 

```python
forecaster = ExponentialSmoothing(sp=12, seasonal="mul", trend="add")
forecaster.fit(y)  ## store residuals in the forecaster object when fit is called.
```

If we do not want to enforce this (due to storage overhead), then maybe adding an argument to fit called `save_residuals: bool=False` would be nice to have.

```python
forecaster = ExponentialSmoothing(sp=12, seasonal="mul", trend="add")
forecaster.fit(y)                       ## Does not store residuals in the forecaster object when fit is called.
forecaster.fit(y, save_residuals=True)  ## Stores residuals in the forecaster object when fit is called.
```

@ngupta23, why would there be an additional call to `fit`? The `Detrender` calls `fit` then `predict` of the wrapped forecaster, so this calls `fit` only once?

Further, I don't think your suggestion works, since for obtaining residuals you need to not only `fit` but also `predict`.

@fkiraly, usually I would fit the model first and only then evaluate (optional). If someone already has a fitted model in the workflow, then having to wrap it in a `Detrender` to get the residuals (using fit_transform) would force another fit on that and would duplicate the effort.
